Shapez 2 isn’t just a game—it's a hypnotic, beautifully engineered celebration of creativity, logic, and pure factory-building joy. It takes everything magical about the original shapez and amplifies it in every direction: smarter systems, deeper automation, richer complexity, and an absolutely stunning sense of flow once your machine starts humming.

From the very first conveyor belt, the game hooks you with that delightful “just one more improvement” feeling. Every step—cutting, stacking, painting, routing, optimizing—feels like a tiny puzzle that ties into a much larger, incredibly satisfying design. And the moment your blueprint comes to life? Pure dopamine.

The progression is masterfully paced. Early tasks teach you fundamentals without pressure, while later challenges push your brain in the best possible way—encouraging elegant solutions rather than brute force. The clean visual style is both beautiful and functional, letting you focus on the wonderfully tangled web of machinery you're creating without ever feeling overwhelmed.

Performance is smooth even when your factory becomes a sprawling mega-machine, and the soundtrack is the perfect calming companion to hours of creative engineering. This is the kind of game where you sit down “just to check on your belts” and suddenly it’s 2 AM.

If you love automation, puzzle solving, optimization, or that warm, cozy feeling of watching a system you designed run perfectly on its own, Shapez 2 is an absolute masterpiece. It’s relaxing, challenging, and endlessly rewarding.

A must-play for fans of factory games—and a dangerously addictive experience for anyone who enjoys getting lost in a world of pure, satisfying logic.

This is the game that makes me want to have neutral rating option for steam reviews. The game's concept was immediate hook after I played the first part. The same game but with better graphics, space stuff and a bunch more belts and whistles - whether it would be good or not seemed like a no brainer. But the moment you get into the thick of it, pretty quickly you realize that unfortunately there's not that much meat on the bones as you'd expect. If I sum up my whole experience with the game most of the time it just felt like a labor.

Firstly, the game doesn't hide any progression from the player. From the moment you start and go through the tutorial, the game straight up lays in front of you everything you will unlock in your whole 60+ hours of playtime. Every shape, every goal, every task, every unlockable. I still cannot truly understand what were the devs thinking when they took this approach. In the previous game there were no bloated menus, it was simply "See this big cpu looking thing? Feed it the shape it shows in the center and see what happens next". Here you need to open the right menu, scroll through literally a dictionary of shapes and then choose the one you want to do. I assume that maybe the intention was to make shapes feel more important and add some 'attachment' to them. Well, they're not pokemon, and I don't feel attached to them, more so after the goal completion and even more after I tear down the factory I just spent my time working on. In this sence, the game progression and the UI are going complete opposite ways and I just can't shake off this awkward feeling, like I'm playing this game wrong.

The factory building in this part is more complex than in the previous one, and of course as a result there's much more tedium that comes with it, but I don't find it as big of an issue, it is to be expected.

The only other thing I can add is I liked the previous jazzy soundtrack much more, compared to the new ones that have this really annoying reverby mixing and get boring really fast.
So overall the game left me with mixed feelings, on one hand it has good graphics, performs decently well and I don't recall encountering any bugs, but it just feels like there's some fundamental flaw in it's design and the devs didn't make the game they would want to play themselves. Maybe upcoming new gamemode will make it more interesting.

As the game offered me more challenges and more complexity to the shapes, I found myself falling more and more into the latter category, as factory parts became more difficult to troubleshoot, copy/pasting not always working right because I copied on the wrong layer, the repetition of setting up the same supply chain over and over and over again (because the way the paint/shape areas are setup, you can't simply copy/paste blueprints on top, you have to rebuild them each time)

This is the game that makes me want to have neutral rating option for steam reviews. The game's concept was immediate hook after I played the first part. The same game but with better graphics, space stuff and a bunch more belts and whistles - whether it would be good or not seemed like a no brainer. But the moment you get into the thick of it, pretty quickly you realize that unfortunately there's not that much meat on the bones as you'd expect. If I sum up my whole experience with the game most of the time it just felt like a labor.

Firstly, the game doesn't hide any progression from the player. From the moment you start and go through the tutorial, the game straight up lays in front of you everything you will unlock in your whole 60+ hours of playtime. Every shape, every goal, every task, every unlockable. I still cannot truly understand what were the devs thinking when they took this approach. In the previous game there were no bloated menus, it was simply "See this big cpu looking thing? Feed it the shape it shows in the center and see what happens next". Here you need to open the right menu, scroll through literally a dictionary of shapes and then choose the one you want to do. I assume that maybe the intention was to make shapes feel more important and add some 'attachment' to them. Well, they're not pokemon, and I don't feel attached to them, more so after the goal completion and even more after I tear down the factory I just spent my time working on. In this sence, the game progression and the UI are going complete opposite ways and I just can't shake off this awkward feeling, like I'm playing this game wrong.

The factory building in this part is more complex than in the previous one, and of course as a result there's much more tedium that comes with it, but I don't find it as big of an issue, it is to be expected.

The only other thing I can add is I liked the previous jazzy soundtrack much more, compared to the new ones that have this really annoying reverby mixing and get boring really fast.
So overall the game left me with mixed feelings, on one hand it has good graphics, performs decently well and I don't recall encountering any bugs, but it just feels like there's some fundamental flaw in it's design and the devs didn't make the game they would want to play themselves. Maybe upcoming new gamemode will make it more interesting.

Shapez 2 is exactly what it looks like. You harvest shapes, manipulate them, and then chuck them into a vortex, so that you can obtain upgrades to make harvesting, manipulating and chucking them into the vortex easier and more streamlined.

The game is 90% self-driven, so any mistakes that happen in your factory are primarily on you. The game offers basic information on how machines work, but optimizations outside of "Build more buildings" either have yet to be added, or is deferred to the community discord.

For my playthrough, I found myself in one of 2 states: Either I was actively working on a project, tinkering with some portion of the factory I've built, troubleshooting why certain aspect aren't working, solving how they designed the shape, etc. and I was enjoying myself, or I was idling, mindlessly connecting part A to part B, waiting for the next milestone to roll around, experiencing tedium and frustration.

As the game offered me more challenges and more complexity to the shapes, I found myself falling more and more into the latter category, as factory parts became more difficult to troubleshoot, copy/pasting not always working right because I copied on the wrong layer, the repetition of setting up the same supply chain over and over and over again (because the way the paint/shape areas are setup, you can't simply copy/paste blueprints on top, you have to rebuild them each time)

Add on top the fact that the game is very resource intensive even on minimal graphics settings, causing my laptop to overheat on multiple occasions, and the developers locking content behind a paywall (their music selection doesn't even come close to lasting the entire game, much less 40 additional minutes they advertise about), you're better off saving a bit of money and playing the original, as you will get pretty much the same experience for half the cost.

6/10.
